ğŸ’¡ "Chaser Game" Season 2 side story released, exploring President Nishikawa's struggles; creator Matsuyama launches game industry guide for CyberConnect2's 30th anniversary.

**Summary:** This article announces the release of a "Chaser Game" Season 2 side story episode titled "The Law of Positive and Negative," exploring the theme that gaining something requires losing somethingâ€”exemplified by President Nishikawa's dual reality of assuming CC4's presidency while facing life threats. The manga is serialized on Famitsu.com with the next episode scheduled for February 9, 2026, and Volume 14 is currently available for purchase. Coinciding with CyberConnect2's 30th anniversary, creator Hiroshi Matsuyama is releasing a "Game Industry Strategy Guide" on February 16, 2026, designed as a comprehensive resource for aspiring game industry professionals with interview tips and actual portfolios. The article also features current Amazon gaming sales rankings dominated by Minecraft and Roblox gift cards, along with links to related manga series and upcoming game releases.

ğŸ“ å…³é”®è¦ç‚¹ (6 sections)
  • Series Introduction: This is an article about 'Chaser Game' Season 2 Side Story episode titled 'The Law of Positive and Negative'. The manga is serialized on Famitsu.com and focuses on the theme 'to gain something, you must lose something'.
  • Editor's Commentary: The editor notes that the central theme 'to gain something, you must lose something' relates to the current storyline where President Nishikawa becomes CC4's president while his life is being threatened. The next episode will be published on February 9, 2026.
  • Volume 14 Availability: Volume 14 of 'Chaser Game' is available for purchase through Amazon.co.jp and Rakuten Books.
  • New Book Release: Hiroshi Matsuyama is releasing 'Game Industry Strategy Guide' on February 16, 2026, coinciding with CyberConnect2's 30th anniversary. The book serves as a new bible for game industry aspirants and includes job interview insights and actual portfolios from successful applicants.
  • Amazon Sales Rankings: The article displays current Amazon gaming sales rankings, predominantly featuring Minecraft and various Roblox gift cards in the top 5 positions.
  • Related Content Links: The page includes links to related manga series like 'Battlefield Fuga: Steel Melody' and other gaming articles, as well as upcoming game release schedules across multiple platforms.

ğŸ“° Adactio (1 article)

â–¸ Iâ€™m sick. I think itâ€˜s manflu. Symptoms include aches, pains, pouts, and petulance. Please send pics/videos of your dogs and cats to cheer me up.

ğŸ’¡ Developer requests pet photos while sick with flu, receiving supportive community response with numerous cat and dog images.

A developer posted on social media about being sick with flu-like symptoms (humorously termed "manflu"), requesting pet photos/videos for comfort. The community responded with numerous images of their cats, dogs, and other pets, along with supportive messages acknowledging the genuine severity of the illness. Context was provided that the current flu variant is particularly harsh, having knocked people out for extended periods during the holiday season. The post gained traction across platforms (Mastodon, Bluesky) with engagement from multiple community members, demonstrating the supportive nature of the tech community even around lighthearted requests.

ğŸ“ å…³é”®è¦ç‚¹ (5 sections)
  • Original Post Context: Author reports being sick with 'manflu' on January 23rd, 2026, experiencing aches, pains, and general discomfort. Requests pet photos/videos from followers to help improve their mood.
  • Community Pet Responses: Multiple community members respond with photos of their pets including cats (Keiko, Roxy, Itsy, Badger cat), dogs (Lily, Olive, Sir Christopher Wigglebutt), and other animals. Contributors include Pierre Spring, Markus Finell, Mark Norman Francis, Kerry Buckley, Ethan Marcotte, and others.
  • Sympathy and Validation: Respondents acknowledge the legitimacy of 'manflu' symptoms with supportive messages. ManFlu account emphasizes that 'the pain is REAL' and encourages the author to stay strong.
  • Illness Severity Context: Andy Davies notes the current flu variant is particularly severe, mentioning it knocked people out for a week after Christmas. This provides context that the illness is genuinely serious beyond the humorous 'manflu' framing.
  • Social Engagement Metrics: The post received 6 documented likes from various users including Daniel Appelquist, Marijke Luttekes, Andy Davies, Ethan Marcotte, and Ms. Jen throughout January 23rd, 2026. Post was shared across multiple platforms including Mastodon and Bluesky.

ğŸ“° Articles on Smashing Magazine â€” For Web Designers And Developers (1 article)

â–¸ Rethinking â€œPixel Perfectâ€ Web Design

ğŸ’¡ "Pixel perfect" web design, originating from print/fixed GUIs, contradicts the web's fluid nature requiring adaptable, accessible experiences across infinite viewports rather than rigid mockup replication.

The "pixel perfect" concept originated from print design and 1980s-90s GUI development when fixed layouts targeting single resolutions (like 800Ã—600) were feasible, but this approach fundamentally misunderstands the web's fluid nature as articulated in John Allsopp's seminal 2000 article "A Dao of Web Design." The term persists despite being technically impreciseâ€”obscuring whether it refers to colors, spacing, typography, or alignmentâ€”and practically impossible given modern web development targets infinite viewport sizes, pixel densities, and form factors from foldables to spatial interfaces. Static mockups represent singular states with specific content, but real-world implementations must handle dynamic variables like localization, varying text lengths, and different data formats, making rigid pixel-perfect layouts inherently fragile. Modern web perfection instead means building accessible, adaptable experiences that gracefully accommodate device diversity, content variations, and evolving user needs rather than achieving static visual replication of fixed mockups.

ğŸ“ å…³é”®è¦ç‚¹ (6 sections)
  • Pixel Perfect Origins: The "pixel perfect" concept originated from print design and early GUI development in the 1980s-90s, where designers used fixed layouts and table-based HTML with spacer GIFs to achieve exact replication of static mockups. This print-based mindset treated screens as glowing paper, designing for single resolutions like 800Ã—600.
  • Early Challenges Emerged: John Allsopp's 2000 article "A Dao of Web Design" challenged pixel-perfection as a "ritual" that ignored the web's inherent fluidity. Despite Responsive Web Design gaining momentum in 2010, the outdated term persists in modern development vocabularies.
  • Fundamental Vagueness Problem: "Pixel perfect" lacks technical specificity and is an all-encompassing blanket statement that obscures actual requirements. When designers request pixel-perfection, it's unclear whether they mean colors, spacing, typography, alignment, or all aspects simultaneously.
  • Multi-Surface Reality: Modern web development targets infinite viewport varieties, resolutions, pixel densities, and form factors including foldables and spatial interfaces. A design "perfect" on one device is inherently imperfect on others, making fixed pixel implementation technically impossible.
  • Dynamic Content Challenges: Static mockups represent single states with specific data, but real-world content varies through localization, different text lengths, currency symbols, and date formatting. Pixel-perfect layouts built for specific content become fragile and collapse when variables change.
  • Accessibility As Perfection: True perfection in modern web design means creating accessible, adaptable experiences that work across devices, content variations, and user needs rather than achieving static visual replication.
